main event: On August 13, 1949, an object reportedly fell to the pavement at the intersection of Canal and Bourbon Streets in New Orleans, Louisiana. The object was described as pie-shaped, apparently made of metal alloy with a sooty exterior and a silvery-gray color underneath.
interesting points: The object was reported to have varied in thickness from approximately 1/16 inch to 1/2 inch and appeared to have been broken from a larger piece.
Eyewitnesses heard a sharp explosion followed by a whirring sound, which ended with the clattering of a piece of metal to the pavement.
The eyewitnesses described a noise similar to a ventilator, and there was no evidence of exhaust or any odor connected with the object.
A news vendor at the intersection reportedly observed the object, and a crowd soon gathered, urging the news vendor to contact the newspaper and report the sighting as a 'flying disc.'
Subsequent examination of buildings adjacent to the area where the object allegedly fell yielded no source for the object.
sighted object: pie-shaped metal object with sooty exterior and silvery-gray color underneath
witnesses: multiple eyewitnesses including a police officer, a railroad employee, and a news vendor
